body:
> Honestly it’s a terrible, anti-good faith and anti-free speech feature.

Not really, it's their autonomy to not want to speak to you, or let you respond to their comments specifically. That's autonomy, not censorship. I agree with still being able to read the comments from those who have blocked you, but there's little point in letting someone respond to a comment after being blocked. If it was in good faith, you'd just be screaming into the void.

Whether or not they choose to be a dick with the tools is another thing. What @captainmeta4 could implement is a cooldown period of 8-24 hours after unblocking a user.
body_html:
Honestly it’s a terrible, anti-good faith and anti-free speech feature.

Not really, it's their autonomy to not want to speak to you, or let you respond to their comments specifically. That's autonomy, not censorship. I agree with still being able to read the comments from those who have blocked you, but there's little point in letting someone respond to a comment after being blocked. If it was in good faith, you'd just be screaming into the void.

Whether or not they choose to be a dick with the tools is another thing. What @captainmeta4 could implement is a cooldown period of 8-24 hours after unblocking a user.

body:
Taking another person's autonomy away is censorship, no matter if that action itself is autonomous.

If you don't want to interact with someone, blocking them should stop you from seeing what they post, not the other way around. Simply because the current implementation is rife with abuse.

parent.body:
> Honestly it’s a terrible, anti-good faith and anti-free speech feature.

Not really, it's their autonomy to not want to speak to you, or let you respond to their comments specifically. That's autonomy, not censorship. I agree with still being able to read the comments from those who have blocked you, but there's little point in letting someone respond to a comment after being blocked. If it was in good faith, you'd just be screaming into the void.

Whether or not they choose to be a dick with the tools is another thing. What @captainmeta4 could implement is a cooldown period of 8-24 hours after unblocking a user.

Besides, being upset over people choosing to do it says a lot about who someone is as a person.

It's about on par with complaining about Fediverse domain blocking, except that there the operator of the server has every right to do so as they please. But as with all tools, it can be used for good or malicious intent.
